How does a University have Constitutional Rights? There is only one constitutional right enumerated in the U.S. Constitution for U.S. Citizens, the others are protections against violating an individual's inalienable rights. So, how does a University become an "individual" under the Constitution and gain standing to have those Constitutional protections? And, "Democracy"? The founders, and James Madison, took very careful steps to safeguard the U.S. from becoming a Democracy. The word itself does not appear in the U.S. Constitution, and for good reason. If you read about the Constitutional Convention and the intent of the authors of the Constitution, you may see that Trump is attempting to fix what has happened to the U.S. Unfortunately, I don't think there is a way to fix what has happened to the U.S.  It's too far gone, given that politicians and the media keep referring to the U.S. as a Democracy or a "Free Democracy." Harvard‚Äôs $52 billion endowment makes it the richest university in the world, and Trump‚Äôs attempt to revoke the university‚Äôs tax exempt status would be a severe blow to its ability to raise funds and attract top notch students and faculty.

Trump is also now escalating the fight, demanding to know Harvard‚Äôs source of foreign funds. Can the school withstand the disinfectant of sunlight?

‚ÄúTax exempt status, I mean, it‚Äôs a privilege, it‚Äôs really a privilege,‚Äù Trump said this week. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs been abused by a lot more than Harvard. It‚Äôs something that these schools really have to be very, very careful with.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a question many Americans may now be asking: Why should Harvard and other Ivy League schools be tax exempt?

They don‚Äôt provide a service to the average person. The average person‚Äôs kids can‚Äôt go to Harvard. The school is the very definition of elitism.

Yet Harvard has decided to take Trump on, refusing to yield to the president‚Äôs demands after Trump froze $2.2 billion in funding.

Who‚Äôs their consultant, Claudine Gay?

Trump is not legally allowed to force the IRS to revoke tax exempt status, but the IRS claims it launched its own investigation into the matter before Trump made it a priority. The law says if you‚Äôre a tax exempt organization you can‚Äôt take political positions ‚Äî a strict limitation that Harvard and others may be violating.

While calling Harvard a ‚Äúdisgrace‚Äù and ‚Äúobviously antisemitic,‚Äù Trump said there had been no final decision on making the university lose its tax status. But the president is not stopping at Harvard. The Trump administration is withholding millions in federal funds to Maine to get the state to change its policy on allowing transgender athletes to compete against girls and women.

Trump is also employing the pocketbook strategy to punish public media like PBS ‚Äî pulling back federal funds because of their liberal bias.

It‚Äôs a battle of populism vs. elitism, and one that Trump hopes to have the public on his side.

Locally, tax exempt Harvard is consistently dragging its feet to make payments in lieu of taxes to the city of Boston, a battle every mayor has had to engage in in recent years.

If the IRS revokes the tax exempt status of Harvard and other universities it could have a major impact on the city‚Äôs efforts to collect payments.

Harvard is known for discriminating Asian Americans in favor of  blacks. 

"The lawsuit, Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) v. Harvard, alleges that Harvard's admissions process discriminates against Asian American applicants by using subjective personality ratings and other factors to lower their overall scores. While Harvard has denied the claims, the lawsuit has highlighted concerns about the use of race-conscious admissions policies and their potential impact on different racial groups. The Supreme Court's decision in June 2023, which struck down race-conscious admissions policies, has further complicated the debate. "

SFFA sued Harvard in 2013, alleging that the university's admissions practices violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discriminating against Asian Americans. The lawsuit claims that Harvard uses subjective factors, such as personality and likability, to unfairly penalize Asian American applicants, resulting in lower overall scores. 
Harvard's Defense:

Harvard has consistently denied these allegations, arguing that its admissions process is comprehensive and considers multiple factors, not just race. The university has also pointed to the fact that the percentage of Asian Americans admitted to Harvard has increased over the years, demonstrating that they are not being excluded from the university. 
Supreme Court Decision:
In June 2023, the Supreme Court ruled against race-conscious admissions policies, effectively banning affirmative action at colleges and universities. This decision, while not specifically addressing the Harvard case, has broader implications for higher education admissions practices, potentially impacting the representation of various racial groups.

‚ÄãThe issue is in the DEI frameworks themselves.
The goal is often to increase representation of certain ethnicities or genders to meet targets or ‚Äúbalance‚Äù demographics.
That means race and sex are not just background details ‚Äì they become factors in the decision-making, alongside or even above merit.
If the goal was only to hire or admit the best individuals, identity wouldn‚Äôt need to be part of the process.
So by definition, DEI shifts focus from individual qualifications to group identity.
That‚Äôs the problem. It‚Äôs not inclusion when someone is left out for not being the ‚Äúright‚Äù sex or ethnicity.
I think the bigger question that is lost in this conversation is: "How do Americans feel about federal funds in the amount of $2b going to one institution?"

OK...while I applaud Harvard for standing up to the Orange Emperor, the tone of the reporting again, CNN, reeks of "Champagne Liberal".  I know that as I am watching this, the first thing I am thinking is: why does Harvard get (or need) $2.2 billion in public money?  And if I am thinking it, so are a lot of others.  

It has a $30 billion endowment, the largest of any academic institution in the US (and probably the reason it can defy this order), and an enrollment of a very elite 25k individuals - about 60% the amount of a state university like UGA or University of Alabama (both averaging around 40-45k students).  

No state university has the endowment money Harvard does, and they receive the same or less in funding - so what gives?  And we all *know* our local community colleges and smaller 4-year colleges aren't seeing any of that money, because they are getting it from the students, or rather from the loans that are piled onto the backs of the students.  Which brings up the issue that a non-zero amount of those attending Harvard - which again, receives a $2.2 billion grant yearly from the government - will graduate with a crippling student loan debt, which they racked up while attending an institution that was accepting grant money paid for by their tax dollars. 

All of this is to say, that as a person who is college educated and interacts on a regular basis with people who are not, I can tell you that from their perspective this $2.2 billion is practically piled up and set on fire every year for all they care.  When you do these spots, you need to do a little better job of explaining *why* Harvard needs or should get $2.2 billion in federal money, because this is how the Propagandists on the RIght and the Authoritarians win.

My daughter attended the HNMUN: Harvard National Model United Nations conference in february representing Utrecht University Model United Nations, the Dutch deligation. HNMUN serves as a forum in which students from colleges and universities around the world can meet to discuss the greatest challenges facing the world today, in fields ranging from international peace and security to economic and social progress and human rights. In this spirit, the goal of HNMUN is to begin a process whereby constructive debate today can lead to solutions tomorrow. HNMUN is the oldest, largest, and most prestigious Model UN conference of its kind. Harvard leads the rest of the world by example.
People that attend this conference are carefully selected in their own country as a delegate; in the Netherlands only around 10% of all applicants is selected to be a delegate. The students from all over the world that attend most of the time end up in high positions in government, UN etc.

John Adams, the second President of the United States and a key Founding Father, offered a stark warning about the fragility of democracy. He wrote:

"Democracy will soon degenerate into an anarchy, such an anarchy that every man will do what is right in his own eyes, and no man's life or property or reputation or liberty will be secure. Every one of these will soon mould itself into a system of subordination of all the moral virtues and intellectual abilities, all the powers of wealth, beauty, wit, and science, to the wanton pleasures, the capricious will, and the execrable cruelty of one or a very few."

Adams believed that unchecked democracy could quickly spiral into chaos, ultimately paving the way for tyranny by a small group or even a single ruler. His words serve as a reminder of the importance of strong institutions, the rule of law, and civic virtue to safeguard liberty and prevent the concentration of power. This perspective remains relevant in evaluating any administration, including the Trump administration, as it underscores the ongoing need for vigilance against the erosion of democratic norms and protections.
